content.description: Wingman is rather consistent, without a single crux. There are lots of moves near the grade at and above bolts -- surprising, compared to the other very soft bolted routes here.
content.location: It is the second route from the left on the upper section. The second bolt is in a left-facing corner.

content.description:
This is an adventurous pitch, thanks to loose, dirty rock and baffling bolt locations. Anchor your belayer to the drilled angle piton on the south end of the big ledge. Move up a few feet, and traverse straight left for about 15 feet, passing above two bolts that are hard to clip. Then angle left-ish, and follow the way of least resistance to the third bolt. A fall from below the third bolt could put you on the rocks in the approach gully. After clipping it, I climbed down and unclipped the second bolt, so my second wouldn’t be faced with a nasty swinging fall. Traversing to the first bolt was scary enough.

Above the third bolt, I climbed to a ledge and placed a #3 WC Friend (modern size) to protect getting to the fourth bolt. I could have placed smaller sizes, but I wanted to save those for the unknown yet to come. Getting to that fourth bolt was difficult and required trial-and-error routefinding. Above it were more difficult moves to a ledge, where I placed a good 2.5 Tricam. Above, a short crack took a red Totem and a bombproof #8 Stopper placed endways. Above the fifth bolt, I could see the chains.
content.protection: The first two of the five bolts should be relocated. I placed a #12 Stopper endways, to protect the start, and other gear as mentioned in the description.
content.location:
Start at the base of

Little Wing

, and traverse straight left, past two equally low bolts.

The route line on the photo is worse than “approximate.” For one thing, the top of

Green Room

is only ten feet left of this route’s anchor, and it doesn’t show the long low traverse at the start.

content.description: This route, on the upper tier, is in the middle of the wall and starts off a small, detached flake. A steep and technical start leads to a slightly runout upper section where gear can be found in a small crack. The original finish leads up and left to an anchor at the top of the wall, or it is possible to traverse up and right to the anchor for Red Zone. This was one of the original routes on the wall. It is a great route.
content.protection: Bolts and a piece of small gear (green Alien).

content.description: Climb through some bulges down low, and then it eases out a bit.
content.protection: Bolts and a green Alien at the top.  The cam isn't really needed.  There are ring anchors at the top.
content.location:
Look at Chosspector's awesome

Topo.

.  It is about 100 yards right from the main area.  There is a large tree left of the anchors.

content.description:
The name and grade are based on the MP

Topo.

posted by

chosspector

.

... a little soft for the grade.
content.location: This is the second route in from the right on the lower tier.

content.description: This is a good climb with lots of features, tons of feet, and is well-bolted.

Red Zone has good, technical climbing on really good rock. The crux is down low, but I wouldn't say it's "short lived," as in Nelson's old guidebook; the climbing stays pretty on you until through the roof.
content.location:
This is just right of

The Stripe

and heads up the clean grey panel and out the roof.

content.description:
Climb the overhanging headwall to the right of the upper tier. Start off a

via ferrata

of sorts, climb some moderate terrain, then pull through the roof onto the face and a sea of relentless crimps.
content.location: Climb the overhanging headwall to the right of the upper tier.

content.description: A slippery start leads to a sneaky, whitish bulge, and otherwise it is pretty straightforward.
content.location: Right as you climb up to the upper section, there are two first bolt options (left for a stick clip, right if you're a purist willing to risk falling down that little chimney scramble).

content.description: This is a great climb with a fun crux area towards the top.  It is easier to belay on the flat spot down by the small spire of rock. More like 75 feet of vertical and 15 feet of scrambling.
content.protection: All bolts to some ring anchors.
content.location: It is all the way left. Belay to the south of the small spire.

content.description: This has a crimpy start to a crux pulling through the peg band. It is a good route.
content.location:
This is one route left of

The Stripe

on the main ledge. It is the third route from the left.

content.description: This has a hard start and is a little run out, but it is a great climb! You should be solid at this grade to lead this.
content.location: This is on the lower wall, it is the second climb from the left.

content.description: The crux is probably the start.  It is fun, but don't fall on this one!
content.protection:
3 bolts to chains.  It shares an anchor with

Chong

.
content.location:
This is left of

Chong

on the lower tier.

content.description: This is a fun route on very good rock. Start on the right side of the ledge on a detached pillar.

The name and grade are based on the MP

Topo.

posted by

chosspector

.

It is tightly bolted (and a little soft) and may be a good beginner sport lead.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: This is the farthest-right route on the lower tier.
